Award.AwardTitle: CNIC: U.S.-Denmark Collaboration on Strategies to Improve Efficiency and Reliability in Microgrids
Award.AbstractNarration:
Through this project development effort, a small research team from Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis (IUPUI) will initiate cooperative research with Danish partners from the Institute of Energy Technology at Aalborg University. Together, the U.S.-Danish team will examine challenges associated with microgrid and power converter architectures that affect current efficiency and reliability. Their approach involves modeling, simulating and experimentally validating newly proposed architectures with arrangements of two- and four-phase microgrids and interfacing power converters. The U.S. team's strengths in modeling and simulation of microgrids and converters complement the Danish partners' expertise in renewable energy systems, power electronics and energy efficiency. With the goal of reducing energy losses while increasing system efficiency, they will start by designing a proof-of-concept setup to emulate an actual microgrid system. The team hopes that their two-phase and four-phase designs will provide a new choice of two ways to move power, either through line-to-line connection or through phase voltages, making it possible to reduce complexity and expense compared to conventional systems requiring larger voltage changes. Specifically, the researchers plan to develop, analyze and validate several designs to demonstrate the advantages, through simulation, design, and experimental tests.

This developmental project fulfills the program objective of catalyzing new international collaboration to advance engineering research on next-generation microgrids for power distribution systems. Preliminary results also are expected to improve our understanding of the potential for new fault tolerant power electronics converters that operate after a fault occurs. If successful, this research could lead to increases in system efficiency with less cost to society and the environment. The ultimate goal is to help build a new electric power distribution system capable of handling more renewable energy sources and more rechargeable cars, at minimum cost and without loss of reliability. Broader impacts also include contributions to the future training of U.S. students, through the preparation of a new IUPUI course, "Microgrid Systems," and by providing one participating Indiana University graduate student with first hand, early career international research experience at Aalborg University in a growing engineering field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we have started an international collaboration dealing with new arrangements of microgrids and interfacing power converters. The tasks of this project were carried out by teams from the U.S. and Denmark. The US team, led by the PI at Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis (IUPUI),  handled the modeling, simulation, and experimental validation of the proposed two-phase microgrid. The PI and one graduate student visited the Institute of Energy Technology-Aalborg University, Denmark to perform the experimental tests on a proof-of-concept setup. The Denmark team was led by Dr. Frede Blaabjerg as well as an assistant professor and a grad student. The Denmark team designed the proof-of-concept setup and provided facilities and technical support for the US team.

During the first six months of this project the US team worked on modeling the proposed two-phase microgrid system to match the real system available in the laboratory at the Institute of Energy Technology-Aalborg University. The hardware available in Denmark for implementation of the proposed system was constituted by Danfoss FC302 2.2 kW inverters operating at 10 kHz and controlled by dSPACE DS1103 systems. Notice from Fig. 1 that the power line with voltages in quadrature was implemented with one and two inverters.

During the three-week technical visit to the Institute of Energy Technology-Aalborg University (from May 19th to June 7th 2014) the US team along with the colleagues from Denmark worked on the experimental validation of the two-phase microgrid. The last months of this project were dedicated primarily on writing papers to publish the results of these collaborative research activities in conferences and technical journals. Two conference papers were published as a direct result of this project, as shown below.  

[1] M. Alibeik, E.C. dos Santos, F. Blaabjerg, “Symmetrical components and power analysis for a two-phase microgrid system,” IEEE PECI 2014 - Power and Energy Conference at Illinois, 2014 , pp.1,8, Feb. 28 2014-March 1 2014.

[2] M. Alibeik, E. C. dos Santos Jr., Y. Yang, X. Wang and F. Blaabjerg. “Single-Phase Active Power Filter For Selective Harmonic Elimination Based On Synchronous Frame Control System”. IEEE APEC 2014 - Applied Power Electronics Conference and Exposition, pp. 1002-1007, March 16-20, Fort Worth, TX.

Both teams are currently working on journal papers that will be submitted within the next months and the PI will include the experience of this project on the development of a new course called Smart Grid.
